title: Single-image Reflectance and Transmittance Estimation from Any Flatbed Scanner
author: Carlos Rodriguez-Pardo (Politecnico di Milano), David Pascual-Hernandez (Universidad Rey Juan Carlos), Javier Rodriguez-Vazquez (Arquimea Research Center), Jorge Lopez-Moreno (Universidad Rey Juan Carlos), Elena Garces (Adobe Research), Carlos Rodriguez-Pardo (Universidad Rey Juan Carlos)
relevance_why: The methods developed for reflectance and transmittance estimation could improve training data quality for audio tasks, specifically in generating realistic audio textures based on visual inputs.
background: Estimating the light reflectance and transmittance properties of materials from a single flatbed scanner image, enabling high-resolution material captures for use in various digital applications.
contribution: This paper introduces a technique for accurately estimating material reflectance and transmittance from flatbed scanner images, effectively expanding the usability of common scanning devices for high-fidelity material representation.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing techniques often require specific illumination setups or expensive high-end equipment, limiting their practicality.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work provides a generic framework for material capture that utilizes any flatbed scanner, removing previous lighting constraints and incorporating a cycle-consistency loss mechanism.

key_innovation: The method allows for accurate material digitization using any scanner, including the estimation of transmittance and opacity, enhancing the realism of digital material representations.
real_world_impact: This advancement can significantly enhance industries that rely on accurate material representation, such as digital art, gaming, and architecture. It democratizes high-quality material capture by making it accessible to lower-end scanning devices.
limitations: The method relies on flat surfaces and is limited by the capabilities of the scanning device; complex materials may still present challenges.

new_terms.SVBSDF: **Spatially-Varying Bidirectional Scattering Distribution Function** refers to a model that describes how light is reflected and transmitted across a surface, accounting for variations in material properties across the surface.
new_terms.Delighting: **Delighting** is the process of removing shading and specular reflections from an image to achieve a clearer representation of material properties.
